content.webTitle: Mary Anne Hobbs: 'I've been given licence to dream'

fields.headline: Mary Anne Hobbs: 'I've been given licence to dream'
fields.bodyText: Curating a cohesive line-up with international artists can be a challenge. Sometimes, things fall into place so quickly it seems that serendipity had a hidden hand in proceedings. “These things are often very complex and require a lot of dialogue, because of the way the world works. It’s a remarkable moment when something like this coalesces so quickly,” says Mary Anne Hobbs of her Queens of the Electronic Underground show at the 02 Ritz. “All of the artists involved immediately wanted to do it. It was beautiful for me, with everyone so excited to play alongside the others. We all wondered: ‘Why hasn’t this happened before?’” The DJ’s excitement around the show is evident. Her eagerly awaited night features some of the most creative, groundbreaking electronic artists working today. Hobbs, who worked with MIF previously on 2017’s Dark Matter show, seems genuinely thrilled to be able to bring Jlin, Holly Herndon, Katie Gately, Klara Lewis and Aïsha Devi together for the festival: “We’re breaking new ground here. As a creator, I’ve been given licence to dream.” From Devi’s collaboration with visual artist MFO and Jlin’s choreography-inspired beats, to Herndon’s adventures in AI creativity, the show promises to be a state-of-the-art audiovisual spectacular. A fierce advocate for female artists from across all genres (her 6 Music show features a weekly All Queens Mix), Hobbs was keen to provide a showcase for female creativity: “The show is a major creative statement, with feminism imbued in that. There are so many women making music of every flavour and texture. If you can create moments like this to give these women a special platform, it’s the greatest step for feminism you can make.” She continues: “I’m asked all the time, ‘Where are the women making electronic music?’ If you don’t know, you’re looking in all the wrong places.” The MIF19 show is certainly the right place. And it’s just a taste of the talent to be found working in electronic music: “We could probably do six months of shows, every night if we wanted to. It’s a real joy for me.” Queens of the new age Mary Anne Hobbs talks us through what to expect from each artist at the showcase Holly Herndon: “One of the most exciting pioneers of electronic music today. Holly is building whole new relationships with machines and AI. I think she really understands the value of integration with technology. She’s creating high art collaboratively in new ways by mentoring and teaching machines. “She told me herself: ‘It’s going to be wild.’” Jlin: “A footwork artist, her rhythm patterns are the most exciting you’ll hear anywhere in the world today. Jlin is a pivotal addition to this bill. You’ll see a set that you won’t be able to experience in any other place, she’s making it specifically for this moment. It makes my heart sing.” Katie Gately: “Color was extraordinary: it’s a subversive, dazzling modern pop record. Katie’s a fascinating sound designer, working with found sounds and also creating the sounds she wants to use herself. “She’s ready to step on from where she left off with Color, and introduce us to a brand new palette.” Klara Lewis: “Klara makes very minimal, brooding, angular music. She calls it ‘theatre for the ear’. I’ve wanted to work with her for a long time, and I’ve always been fascinated by how her work will be interpreted in a live space. I can’t wait to see how it unfolds.” Aïsha Devi: “Aïsha is a highly unpredictable, really radical artist. She’s based in Berlin, and is really interested in the rituals of club life and club music. She’s working with a visual artist called MFO on a special collaborative piece, which is the initial reason we put a huge screen into the venue. It’s incredibly exciting.” • Queens of the Electronic Underground is at the O2 Ritz, Whitworth Street West, Manchester M1 5NQ on 20 July • The Guardian is a media partner of Manchester international festival.
